abstract.p: This memorandum provides a list of answers to queries about agriculture and revenue collection in district (pargana) Dhar regarding types of land, terms of land tenure, expenses for cultivation, and sale of land holdings. It is a document fragment.

Yadi written in articles [by] Nal Shahun Ali, [containing] his
answers for the pargana Dhar in the Suhur year twenty, two
hundred and one thousand [i.e. 1220], or the year 12271227 appears to be a Fasli year; however, it does not correspond to the Suhur year 1220 written earlier in the document using terms derived from the Arabic words for numbers. Whereas Shaʿban 1227 converts to June/July 1817 of the Gregorian calendar, Shaʿban 1220 yields a date of May/June 1820. The document also references the Hindu intercalary month Adhik Jyeshta, which is inserted to reconcile lunar and solar modes of reckoning time. Within the period in question, the months Adhik Jyeshta and Shaʿban coincided at the end of the Suhur year 1220; hence, we determine that the document is most accurately dated to May/June 1820. in the month of Shaʿban, or
Adhik Jyeshtha
4 items
1 How many thousands of bighas are
part of the grounds of the village in total?
1 How much land is cultivated, and within that, today
how much is cultivated and fallow?
1 How much pasture and grassland?
1 How much is merely wasteland?
--
4
In total, answers to the four articles [by way of] a land survey
in the prant has never happened.
If ordered, we will carry out a land survey, and one or two
villages’ estimates according to their four boundaries
will be taken. [However] the whole pargana’s will not happen.
It will require many days so a boundary-wise survey
has never happened. If it will please,
we will carry out the survey of one or two villages.
1 How much land do the watandars in the villages have?
In answer to this, details on a separate
paper have written, and via the jamadar’s
agent, have been sent.
According, write this.Article 1
In the khalsa lands, they conduct agriculture.
In what manner does its revenue come in? So it
it is ordered.Article 1
In answer to this, [whoever] does agriculture,
deducts advances for seeds, provisions, and other expenses.
Every good that will be produced out of the land
will be taken by the landlord or if given to the cultivator,
[from] each bigha will be taken

1 Are the lands held by the watandars governed [taxed]
or not?Article 1
In answer to this, the procedure [is that] in the third year, a pishkash,
meaning a general sum according to the rupee system,
on the cultivated lands is taken. So is the practice
in the pargana.Article
1 Do the inʿamdars of the lands give anything to the government
or not?Article 1
The custom is that if a landlord has acquired a command [post]
in the government, people look to take shares.
1 [Regarding] those non-residential tenants who work the land,
[what is] the procedure?Article 1
The procedure [is that] in the village, [on] each bigha one
rupee, six annas and the procedure [for] non-residential tenancies, one
rupee, two annas and one rupee and twelve annas;
so is [the procedure].Article 1
1 [Regarding] the watandars who work their patrimonial lands
and if khalsa lands are worked,
by which procedure are [revenues] taken?Article 1
The procedure [is that] if household [lands] are worked, seed,
buffaloes, and wages for laborers will be required. The landlord will give,
and he should take his [share] from the resulting yield, or
if they are worked through a cultivator, twelve
annas according to the rupee system from the cultivators
used to be taken. Seed, provisions, wages, and various other expenses
by sheer custom used to be taken by the landlord [on] the head of the cultivator.
They used to take deductions on account of the actions of heaven and king.The phrase is asmani-sultani, meaning any unforeseen disaster caused by divine or secular power, such as a drought or an invasion. Article 1
1 Are the watandars able to sell their lands
or not?Article 1
The procedure [is that] even if one is a full watandar,
one sells or pawns one’s land.
The court has no claim over
that whatsoever. He does so
at his pleasure.Article 1
